PAL.NAME: Microsoft Lync 2010
PAL.DESCRIPTION: Created by using data from the Lync 2010 Key Health Indicators published in the Microsoft Lync Networking Guide. (http://aka.ms/lyncnetguide)

ANALYSIS.NAME: LS:CAA - 00 - Operations CAA - 000 - Incomplete calls per sec

DATASOURCE.NAME: \LS:CAA - 00 - Operations\CAA - 000 - Incomplete calls per sec

CHART.CHARTTITLE: \LS:CAA - 00 - Operations\CAA - 000 - Incomplete calls per sec
CHART.DATASOURCE: \LS:CAA - 00 - Operations\CAA - 000 - Incomplete calls per sec

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The per second rate of incomplete calls to Conferencing Attendant. This includes calls disconnected by the user and by the system due to invalid conference id, passcode, etc.

ANALYSIS.NAME: LS:USrv - 01 - DBStore\USrv - 002 - Queue Latency USrv - 002 - Queue Latency (msec)
ANALYSIS.PRIMARYDATASOURCE: \LS:USrv - 01 - DBStore\USrv - 002 - Queue Latency (msec)

DATASOURCE.NAME: \LS:USrv - 01 - DBStore\USrv - 002 - Queue Latency (msec)
DATASOURCE.EXPRESSIONPATH: \LS:USrv - 01 - DBStore\USrv - 002 - Queue Latency (msec)

CHART.CHARTTITLE: \LS:USrv - 01 - DBStore\USrv - 002 - Queue Latency (msec)
CHART.DATASOURCE: \LS:USrv - 01 - DBStore\USrv - 002 - Queue Latency (msec)

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION:
Queue latency is the amount of time (in milliseconds) that it takes for a request to leave the Front End Serverâ€™s queue toward the back-end database. If this value by itself is high, you may have be encountering a network problem between FE->SQL. If this value is high and Sproc Latency is high, it is most commonly a bottom-neck with the SQL backend.

Spikes are expected during peak hours, look for sustatined values above 100 ms.

ANALYSIS.NAME: LS:USrv - 01 - DBStore\USrv - 004 - Sproc Latency USrv - 004 - Sproc Latency (msec)
ANALYSIS.PRIMARYDATASOURCE: \LS:USrv - 01 - DBStore\USrv - 004 - Sproc Latency (msec)

DATASOURCE.NAME: \LS:USrv - 01 - DBStore\USrv - 004 - Sproc Latency (msec)
DATASOURCE.EXPRESSIONPATH: \LS:USrv - 01 - DBStore\USrv - 004 - Sproc Latency (msec)

CHART.CHARTTITLE: \LS:USrv - 01 - DBStore\USrv - 004 - Sproc Latency (msec)
CHART.DATASOURCE: \LS:USrv - 01 - DBStore\USrv - 004 - Sproc Latency (msec)

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION:
Sproc latency is the amount of time (in milliseconds) that it takes for the database to process the request. This performance value is collected from the time the request leaves the Front End Server queue until that the request returns. If this value by itself is high, it is likely a bottleneck with the SQL backend.

Spikes are expected during peak hours, look for sustatined values above 100 ms.

ANALYSIS.NAME: LS:USrv - 01 - DBStore USrv - 020 - Throttled requests/sec
ANALYSIS.PRIMARYDATASOURCE: \LS:USrv - 01 - DBStore\USrv - 020 - Throttled requests/sec

DATASOURCE.NAME: \LS:USrv - 01 - DBStore\USrv - 020 - Throttled requests/sec
DATASOURCE.EXPRESSIONPATH: \LS:USrv - 01 - DBStore\USrv - 020 - Throttled requests/sec

CHART.CHARTTITLE: \LS:USrv - 01 - DBStore\USrv - 020 - Throttled requests/sec
CHART.DATASOURCE: \LS:USrv - 01 - DBStore\USrv - 020 - Throttled requests/sec

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The number of requests that were rejected/sec with a retry-after since the database queue latency was high.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Memory Available MBytes
ANALYSIS.PRIMARYDATASOURCE: \Memory\Available MBytes

DATASOURCE.NAME: \Memory\Available MBytes
DATASOURCE.EXPRESSIONPATH: \Memory\Available MBytes

CHART.CHARTTITLE: \Memory\Available MBytes
CHART.DATASOURCE: \Memory\Available MBytes

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION:
Available MBytes is the amount of physical RAM, in Megabytes, immediately available for allocation to a process or for system use. It is equal to the sum of memory assigned to the standby (cached), free and zero page lists. If this counter is low, then the computer is running low on physical RAM.
This analysis will alert a Warning if this counter's value is less than 20% of the RAM installed and will alert a critical if this counter's value is less than 10%.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Network Interface Packets Outbound Discarded
ANALYSIS.PRIMARYDATASOURCE: \Network Interface(*)\Packets Outbound Discarded

DATASOURCE.NAME: \Network Interface(*)\Packets Outbound Discarded
DATASOURCE.EXPRESSIONPATH: \Network Interface(*)\Packets Outbound Discarded

CHART.CHARTTITLE: \Network Interface(*)\Packets Outbound Discarded
CHART.DATASOURCE: \Network Interface(*)\Packets Outbound Discarded

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: Packets Outbound Discarded is the number of outbound packets that were chosen to be discarded even though no errors had been detected to prevent transmission. One possible reason for discarding packets could be to free up buffer space.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Network Interface Packets Received Discarded
ANALYSIS.PRIMARYDATASOURCE: \Network Interface(*)\Packets Received Discarded

DATASOURCE.NAME: \Network Interface(*)\Packets Received Discarded
DATASOURCE.EXPRESSIONPATH: \Network Interface(*)\Packets Received Discarded

CHART.CHARTTITLE: \Network Interface(*)\Packets Received Discarded
CHART.DATASOURCE: \Network Interface(*)\Packets Received Discarded

THRESHOLD.NAME: Greater than 0
THRESHOLD.CODE: #// Here is a ready to use example on how to use the StaticThreshold() function to define a threshold: StaticThreshold -CollectionOfCounterInstances $CollectionOfNetworkInterfacePacketsReceivedDiscarded -Operator 'gt' -Threshold 0

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: Packets Received Discarded is the number of inbound packets that were chosen to be discarded even though no errors had been detected to prevent their delivery to a higher-layer protocol. One possible reason for discarding packets could be to free up buffer space.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Processor Information % Processor Time
ANALYSIS.PRIMARYDATASOURCE: \Processor Information(*)\% Processor Time

DATASOURCE.NAME: \Processor Information(*)\% Processor Time
DATASOURCE.EXPRESSIONPATH: \Processor Information(*)\% Processor Time

CHART.CHARTTITLE: \Processor Information(*)\% Processor Time
CHART.DATASOURCE: \Processor Information(*)\% Processor Time

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION:
% Processor Time is the percentage of elapsed time that the processor spends to execute a non-Idle thread. It is calculated by measuring the percentage of time that the processor spends executing the idle thread and then subtracting that value from 100%. (Each processor has an idle thread to which time is accumulated when no other threads are ready to run). This counter is the primary indicator of processor activity, and displays the average percentage of busy time observed during the sample interval. It should be noted that the accounting calculation of whether the processor is idle is performed at an internal sampling interval of the system clock tick. On todays fast processors, % Processor Time can therefore underestimate the processor utilization as the processor may be spending a lot of time servicing threads between the system clock sampling interval. Workload based timer applications are one example of applications which are more likely to be measured inaccurately as timers are signaled just after the sample is taken.

CPU usage greater than 80% on the hottest core should be investigated. Spikes are expected during peak usage times.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Network Interface Output Queue Length
ANALYSIS.PRIMARYDATASOURCE: \Network Interface(*)\Output Queue Length

DATASOURCE.NAME: \Network Interface(*)\Output Queue Length
DATASOURCE.EXPRESSIONPATH: \Network Interface(*)\Output Queue Length

CHART.CHARTTITLE: \Network Interface(*)\Output Queue Length
CHART.DATASOURCE: \Network Interface(*)\Output Queue Length

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION:
Output Queue Length is the length of the output packet queue (in packets). If this is longer than two, there are delays and the bottleneck should be found and eliminated, if possible. Since the requests are queued by the Network Driver Interface Specification (NDIS) in this implementation, this will always be 0.
Indiciator of how busy a network interface is. 0 is health, 1 is busy, 2 is overloaded.

ANALYSIS.NAME: PhysicalDisk Avg. Disk sec/Read
ANALYSIS.PRIMARYDATASOURCE: \PhysicalDisk(*)\Avg. Disk sec/Read

DATASOURCE.NAME: \PhysicalDisk(*)\Avg. Disk sec/Read
DATASOURCE.EXPRESSIONPATH: \PhysicalDisk(*)\Avg. Disk sec/Read

CHART.CHARTTITLE: \PhysicalDisk(*)\Avg. Disk sec/Read
CHART.DATASOURCE: \PhysicalDisk(*)\Avg. Disk sec/Read

THRESHOLD.NAME: Greater than 25 ms
Greater than 10 ms

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION:
Avg. Disk sec/Read is the average time, in seconds, of a read of data from the disk.

Drives that do not contain Lync databases can be ignored. A key measure of disk latency representing the average time, in milliseconds, of each read to disk where > 20 is poor, < 20 is good/fair, < 12 is better, < 8 is best.

ANALYSIS.NAME: PhysicalDisk Avg. Disk sec/Write
ANALYSIS.PRIMARYDATASOURCE: \PhysicalDisk(*)\Avg. Disk sec/Write

DATASOURCE.NAME: \PhysicalDisk(*)\Avg. Disk sec/Write
DATASOURCE.EXPRESSIONPATH: \PhysicalDisk(*)\Avg. Disk sec/Write

CHART.CHARTTITLE: \PhysicalDisk(*)\Avg. Disk sec/Write
CHART.DATASOURCE: \PhysicalDisk(*)\Avg. Disk sec/Write

THRESHOLD.NAME: Greater than 25 ms
Greater than 10 ms

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION:
Avg. Disk sec/Write is the average time, in seconds, of a write of data to the disk.

Drives that do not contain Lync databases can be ignored. A key measure of disk latency representing the average time, in milliseconds, of each write to disk, where non-cached writes ( > 20 poor, < 20 fair, < 12 better, < 8 best) differ significantly from cached writes (> 4 poor, < 4 fair, < 2 better, < 1 best ). For OLTP databases, the lower this number the better, especially for disks holding the transaction log.

ANALYSIS.NAME: SQLServer:Buffer Manager Page life expectancy
ANALYSIS.PRIMARYDATASOURCE: \SQLServer:Buffer Manager\Page life expectancy

DATASOURCE.NAME: \SQLServer:Buffer Manager\Page life expectancy
DATASOURCE.EXPRESSIONPATH: \SQLServer:Buffer Manager\Page life expectancy

CHART.CHARTTITLE: \SQLServer:Buffer Manager\Page life expectancy
CHART.DATASOURCE: \SQLServer:Buffer Manager\Page life expectancy

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: Avg. in seconds how long SQL Server expects a data page to stay in cache. The target is at least 300 (5 min). When under 300, this may indicate a potential shortage of memory.

CHART.DATASOURCE: \SQLServer:Memory Manager\Memory Grants Pending

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: Total number of processes per second waiting for a workspace memory grant. Numbers higher than 0 indicate a lack of memory.
